description: From Middle English tost, from the verb tosten (see below).

examples: I ate a piece of toast for breakfast.

entries.meaning: (countable) A proposed salutation (e.g. to say "cheers") while drinking alcohol.
examples: At the reception, there were many toasts from the well-wishers.

entries.meaning: (countable) A person, group, or notable object to which a salutation with alcohol is made; a person or group held in similar esteem.
examples: He was the toast of high society.

entries.meaning: (slang, chiefly US, uncountable) Something that will be no more; something subject to impending destruction, harm or injury.
examples: If I ever get my hands on the guy that stole my wallet, he’s toast!

entries.meaning: (slang, Jamaica) Extemporaneous narrative poem or rap.
(computing, graphical user interface) A transient, informational unclickable pop-up overlay, less interactive than a snackbar.

description: From Middle English tosten, from Old French toster (“to roast, grill”), from Latin tostus (“grilled, burnt”), from verb torreō (“to burn, grill”).

verbs.description: toast (third-person singular simple present toasts, present participle toasting, simple past and past participle toasted)

entries.meaning: To lightly cook by browning via direct exposure to a fire or other heat source.
examples: We liked to toast marshmallows around the campfire.

entries.meaning: To grill, lightly cook by browning specifically under a grill or in a toaster
examples: Top with cheese and toast under the grill for a few minutes.

entries.meaning: To engage in a salutation and/or accompanying raising of glasses while drinking alcohol in honor of someone or something.
examples: We toasted the happy couple many times over the course of the evening.
I toasted my feet by the fire.

entries.meaning: (slang, Jamaica) To perform extemporaneous narrative poem or rap.
